audio_caption: The audio clip begins with two male speakers, one introducing the other as Stephen Jaffey and thanking him for joining the segment, with a friendly and conversational tone. Stephen replies in kind, expressing his pleasure to be back. The first speaker then remarks on Stephen's tiredness, suggesting he is in the midst of a campaign, prompting Stephen to elaborate on why he decided to run, emphasizing San Francisco's need for a voice in Congress, particularly as the current incumbent is out of touch with her constituents. He states his intention to give San Francisco the voice it deserves and needs in Congress, in summary.

The audio begins with a male speaker discussing the political landscape, mentioning San Francisco and the person being replaced, whom he describes as a nationally recognized progressive. The speaker praises the other person's efforts and mentions issues within the Democratic Party, including a lawsuit, requesting more information.  There are no sounds of music or background noise present during this clip.

The audio clip features a male speaker who is critical of a specific California policy. The speaker describes this policy, mentioning that incumbents who are running for the same office receive an automatic endorsement of the state party. He further notes that the only way to challenge it is for the challenger to collect 20% of the signatures of all the delegates in the relevant district. Overall, the speaker seems concerned.

The audio begins with a male speaker describing an event, mentioning turning in signatures and being told they were not enough because "the state party said it was using a list with more delegates." His tone is conversational and informative, explaining how "they changed the rules after the game was over." Another male speaker responds, saying, "Sure, they cheated." The first speaker replies, "Well, thank you," then summarizes that the litigation is about them not being able to change the rules. He concludes that this "that's the substance of the lawsuit."

The clip starts with a male speaker acknowledging something and then asking a question. A second male speaker responds, talking about expense and time, and how he feels it's important for progressives not to cave in when certain tactics are used, alluding to a nationwide policy to keep incumbents in office and suppress progressive challengers. He states that he is one of those progressives, mentions a colleague, and alleges cheating kind of allegations, emphasizing that it's important for progressives to stand up. Finally, the first speaker responds, saying "Absolutely."

The clip features a conversation between two people. One, a man, expresses gratitude to the other, stating their words define the difference between progressives and corporate democrats, citing that "one side resisting and not really moving anywhere and another side that's trying to push forward", asserting "we want change. We it's it's time to shake things up". The second speaker, another man, responds affirmatively in a similar tone, remarking that "no incumbent is ever going to voluntarily give up the power they have. It's got to be taken", before stating his intentions "to do" this. The first speaker agrees, mentioning, "it's time to go on the offensive". The clip concludes with the first speaker's appreciation, stating the second speaker "have been on that" before the phrase "we you know" ends the clip.

The clip begins with a male speaker stating that many in the progressive movement understand why Nancy Pelosi is foolish, then asks about specific changes the speaker wants to make in San Francisco, particularly those that are top of mind. The speaker has a measured tone, as if in conversation or an interview.

The audio clip starts with one male speaker discussing the peculiar issues of San Francisco and local governance, emphasizing two main problems: homelessness and the cost of housing, which he describes as "through the roof" and hard to describe. He notes the problems' intersection and attributes homelessness to evictions and gentrification due to corporate democrats pandering to real estate developers and landlords. He concludes by advocating for federal government involvement and the use of available resources.

The audio clip features a single male speaker discussing his plans to address homelessness if elected, saying he would contact FEMA and the Surgeon General to declare a disaster area and health emergency, respectively. He speaks with a straightforward tone, emphasizing his intention to bring in resources to solve a problem that the city is "unwilling or unable to do."

The audio clip features two speakers, one male with a slightly sarcastic tone, questioning another male about taking "immediate direct action." The sarcastic speaker jokes about conducting a study and accuses the other of moving too quickly. The second male speaker acknowledges the sarcasm. The sarcastic speaker states his expectation of faster progress in a progressive state, considering the issues of homelessness and inequality. The other speaker agrees that "one would think so."

The audio clip starts with a male speaker suggesting an idea, followed by his lament that things are worsening, illustrated by San Francisco's ineffective budget for homelessness. Another male voice responds, acknowledging the lack of solutions and hinting at the possible influence of real estate interests on Pelosi's donation list. The first speaker confirms, adding that Pelosi raises a lot of money for the party, but doesnâ€™t disclose her benefactors, who are corporations with a stake in the issues discussed not being solved. The second speaker agrees.

The audio clip begins with two male speakers engaged in a conversation. One speaker is prompting the other to tell the audience where he will be next, mentioning that he is always on the road and asking where they can meet him to show support and hear more from him. The other speaker responds, stating that he will be hitting the streets of San Francisco and that he's been going and running for a year, attending meetings and doing fundraising. He adds that he will be spending most of his time talking to people, handing out literature, and knocking on doors. The first speaker responds with enthusiasm, calling it awesome. He then asks where people can go to support him.

The audio clip begins with a male speaker providing website information. He speaks clearly and enthusiastically, offering two different URLs for donation and stressing their presence on Facebook and Twitter. A second male speaker chimes in in agreement, offering additional instruction on how to mention the first male speaker on Twitter to get a response. The second male speaker then suggests that the listeners help the first speaker because his opponent can raise a lot of money and will then proceed to do nothing for them. The first male speaker then returns to add that she votes for donors, not voter constituents.

The clip begins with a male speaker thanking someone and encouraging them to continue progressive fights. A second male speaker expresses gratitude for being invited back and anticipation for future appearances. The first speaker then suggests doing a town hall or debate with other progressives, mentioning Nancy and inviting her to debate, stating, "Nancy, if you're willing, we're here...or anybody else you'd like to challenge to a debate, call them out right now." The second speaker responds that, "Pelosi has not debated an opponent since 1987." The first speaker then adds, "Here's your chance to practice, Nancy. You're gonna need it." The second speaker agrees, followed by both thanking each other, and then concluding with a "see you later".
